content.description:
The human equivalent of a beaver damn...

Start from the far right and climb to the diagonal rail. Follow that u and right to the top.
content.location: Far right side of the east side (closest to the road).

content.description:
After a beaver harvests trees and builds a dam and lodge, the forest will regenerate with different species than before, and attract different types of animals, promoting biodiversity around the pond.

Climb the West side starting low on a jug with your feet underneath in a crack. A long reach and a heel-hook might help you pull the mini roof, then slab your way to the top. Watch for loose holds!

"Ecosystem Engineers" are animals that significantly affect their environments. Beaver, of course, are the prime example, but others include prairie dogs, woodpeckers, and even caterpillars (who create shelters from leaves).

Hug the arch with underclings and jugs on both sides and work toward the high crux.
content.location: Find the arch and put a hand on either side.

content.description:
Beaver will often dig a canal (30-60cm wide and 20-35cm deep) hundreds of yards long into a forest. Connected to the beaver's pond, the canal floods with water. The beaver will then use this shallow canal to float trees from in the forest out to the pond for construction, or a snack!

Start low on a cool jug with a hole (see photo) and layback/heelhook/pinch your way up sharp rock, staying on the steep arete.
content.location: North (narrow side) of the boulder with several exposed layers of rock breaking down into cool formations.
